Lately, I've been feeling really isolated and disconnected. Since coming out as non-binary and starting to work from home, I feel like I've lost touch with the world around me. I want to make friends and maybe even start dating, but I'm anxious about putting myself out there. I worry about being misgendered or having to explain my identity to new people. And with my freelance work, I don't have the built-in social interactions that come with a traditional job. Sometimes I think about joining LGBTQ+ meetups or trying to connect with other artists, but then I talk myself out of it, fearing rejection or misunderstanding. I miss having a sense of community and genuine connections. Maybe I need to find ways to bridge my online life with real-world interactions and find accepting spaces, but I'm not sure how to start or if I'll be able to find people who understand both my identity and my lifestyle.

I've been feeling increasingly isolated and lonely since taking this new position. The pressure to publish and secure tenure is intense, and I feel like I need to dedicate all my time to research and writing. But this single-minded focus has left me feeling disconnected from my colleagues and the world outside academia. I want to make friends and maybe even explore dating, but I worry that any time spent socializing will jeopardize my career prospects. Sometimes I think about attending faculty socials or joining a community group related to my field, but then I talk myself out of it, feeling guilty for taking time away from my work. I miss having meaningful connections and a life outside of my research. Maybe I need to find a way to balance my academic ambitions with my need for personal relationships, but I'm not sure how to do that in this competitive environment or if it's even possible to have a fulfilling social life while pursuing tenure.
